top.author: @dee_naliaks
top.text: Controlling a revenue worker that handles email, calendar, and CRM all through a simple message is incredible. SuperAgent executes real business, not just chats. AI as workforce, zero chaos.

options.comment: The 'zero chaos' part hits different when you've spent years watching people juggle 17 different productivity apps to do what should be one seamless workflow ğŸ˜…
This is what true AI workforce looks like - not just answering questions but actually executing workflows. The integration challenge across email/calendar/CRM is where most tools still struggle.
As someone building email tools, seeing AI actually execute workflows instead of just suggesting actions is the future. The hardest part is making that integration feel truly seamless.

top.author: @muffydot
top.text: I hate when I have no notifications or an empty inbox I feel empty

options.comment: The modern paradox: we hate notifications but feel invisible without them ğŸ“±ğŸ’”
This is so real. We've created systems where our self-worth depends on digital validation. The empty inbox anxiety is proof our relationship with technology has gotten weird.
As someone building email tools, this hits different... we're trying to solve inbox overwhelm but turns out zero emails creates its own existential crisis ğŸ˜…

top.author: @RemingtonBegg
top.text: Funny story: My wife (and cofounder) helps manage my inbox lately (I KNOW, I'M LUCKY) and asked me, "Who the f**k is Benjamin? Heâ€™s sending you emails every morning with action items before I can." I told her Benjamin isn't a person. Itâ€™s my AI agent from

options.comment: Benjamin sounds like the dream employee - never late, never complains, and works weekends ğŸ˜‚
The moment when AI becomes so seamless it feels like having another team member. Curious what platform/tool you're using for the morning action items workflow?
As someone building email tools, this is exactly the kind of inbox-to-action workflow we're obsessed with. AI that turns email chaos into clear daily priorities ğŸ¯

top.author: @imswapnilpowar
top.text: System Design: Design Email Delivery Service Sends emails from apps to millions of users with high reliability and inbox delivery. Used for OTPs, resets, invoices, alerts, and marketing. The goal is not â€œsend fastâ€ - the goal is reach the inbox, not spam.

top.author: @ChonnyCho
top.text: Use Gmail search shortcuts to find large emails or emails with attachments or emails from this state to that date etc. Delete the hell out of them.

options.comment: The satisfaction of watching that storage number drop after a good purge session is unmatched ğŸ“‰
Gmail search operators are incredibly powerful. `has:attachment larger:10M` is my go-to for finding storage hogs. The real challenge is building sustainable habits around inbox maintenance.
As someone building email tools, I see this pattern all the time - reactive cleanup vs proactive organization. We're exploring ways to make this happen automatically before the 15GB wall hits.

top.author: @ShipAloneCEO
top.text: Do you want the waitlist to just collect emails, or also qualify people (use case, company size) and auto-send a welcome email? That answer usually decides whether I go simple form on a landing page or use a tool.

options.comment: Plot twist: the welcome email gets lost in their promotions tab anyway ğŸ“§

I lean toward starting simple and adding qualification later based on actual user feedback. The friction vs. data quality tradeoff is real, but early validation matters more than perfect segmentation.
As someone building email tools, I've seen too many welcome emails disappear into the void. The qualification vs. simplicity debate is real, but inbox chaos makes even perfect emails invisible.

top.author: @lashea___girll
top.text: Just delete your emails. Literally have access to my mom's email. Got the same message. Deleted all her spam and most of the inbox, the message went away. https:// x.com/thyhighs/statu /thyhighs/status/2016587925224394781 â€¦

options.comment: The nuclear option ğŸ˜… Sometimes starting fresh is genuinely the most therapeutic thing you can do
There's something oddly satisfying about mass deletion. Though the real challenge is preventing that inbox chaos from building up again in the first place.
As someone building email tools, I see this nuclear approach way too often ğŸ˜… The real problem is that inboxes become dumping grounds when there's no smart filtering happening upfront

top.author: @techcoachralph
top.text: Sick of staring at your inbox, wondering if you got ghosted again? These rejections aren't randomâ€”your resume's not making it past the bots. I built ResumeFlow so you can finally see what the robots hate. Find out what the resume robots hate. http:// ResumeFlow.app #jobsearch

options.comment: Plot twist: the bots are also tired of reading terrible resumes ğŸ˜…
The ATS vs human readability tension is real. Most people optimize for one but ignore the otherâ€”then wonder why they're not getting responses.
As someone who deals with inbox chaos daily, I feel the ghosting pain. We're exploring how to surface signal from noiseâ€”applies to job hunting too.

top.author: @tryramen
top.text: The worst part about outsourcing outbound to a VA isnâ€™t wasted spend. Itâ€™s waking up to a toasted domain. One sloppy list + copy/paste emails + zero inbox hygieneâ€¦ and now YOUR name is â€œspam.â€ Truth: delegate the work, not the reputation.

options.comment: Nothing quite like checking your domain reputation and seeing it flatlined ğŸ“‰
The reputation recovery timeline is brutal too. What used to take weeks to build can take months to repair, if ever.
As someone building email tools, this hits different. The sender reputation ecosystem is so fragile - one bad campaign can cascade through every provider.

top.author: @NakedCollector
top.text: The era of the "Inbox VC" is over. You don't need an 8-figure budget to build this. Just the right architecture. I break down the full tech stack and workflow here Link to workflow in first comment: #vc #automation #ai

options.comment: Plot twist: the real "inbox VC" was the automation we built along the way ğŸ¤–
The democratization of deal flow automation is fascinating. What's your take on balancing automated screening vs maintaining those crucial human connections in early-stage investing?
As someone building email automation tools, totally agree that smart architecture beats big budgets. The inbox intelligence layer is where the real magic happens.

top.author: @Luckyjene
top.text: Change who you allow into streams settings your mod settings to allow only phone verified to immediately type and email verified to only type after 10 minutes use Commander roots follower remover tool to get rid of the fake follows that can harm your account If you need help dm

options.comment: The eternal battle against bots and spam... feels like digital whack-a-mole sometimes ğŸ¤–
Smart layered approach. Verification gates + time delays are becoming essential for any platform dealing with high-volume interactions. The manual cleanup tools help too.
As someone working on filtering systems, this reminds me how crucial verification layers are. We're exploring similar approaches for reducing noise in different contexts.

top.author: @jeoste_
top.text: My client just sent me this satisfying email about my "slow shipping" But if I tell my client I need 4 days to do the feature, and they pay me to work 1 day per week, then why are they not happy that it takes 1 month to ship (???)

options.comment: The math is mathing but the client is not ğŸ˜…
Classic expectation vs reality gap. I've learned to include timeline calculations in my project proposals now - makes the math crystal clear upfront.
As someone dealing with communication gaps daily, this hits hard. Clear expectations upfront saves so many follow-up emails later.

top.author: @m0370
top.text: Looking at the email header, DKIM and DMARC are set up, but the sending mail server doesnâ€™t have SPF configured at all! No wonder Gmail marks it as spam. The quoted-printable encoding with ISO-2022-JP also feels a bit outdated. I bet the chances of getting flagged as spam are

comments.tweetTranslationZh: çœ‹é‚®ä»¶å¤´ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ŒDKIM å’Œ DMARC éƒ½é…ç½®äº†ï¼Œä½†å‘é€é‚®ä»¶æœåŠ¡å™¨æ ¹æœ¬æ²¡æœ‰é…ç½® SPFï¼éš¾æ€ª Gmail æŠŠå®ƒæ ‡è®°ä¸ºåƒåœ¾é‚®ä»¶ã€‚ISO-2022-JP çš„ quoted-printable ç¼–ç ä¹Ÿæ„Ÿè§‰æœ‰ç‚¹è¿‡æ—¶äº†ã€‚æˆ‘æ•¢æ‰“èµŒè¢«æ ‡è®°ä¸ºåƒåœ¾é‚®ä»¶çš„å‡ ç‡æ˜¯

options.comment: Missing SPF is like having a bouncer at the front door but no ID check - Gmail's just being cautious with your mystery guest ğŸ˜…
options.comment_zh: ç¼ºå°‘ SPF å°±åƒé—¨å£æœ‰ä¿å®‰ä½†ä¸æ£€æŸ¥èº«ä»½è¯ä¸€æ · - Gmail åªæ˜¯å¯¹ä½ çš„ç¥ç§˜è®¿å®¢ä¿æŒè°¨æ… ğŸ˜…

options.comment: SPF is such a basic authentication step, yet so many legitimate senders skip it. The combo of missing SPF + outdated encoding is basically asking for the spam folder. Modern email infrastructure really shouldn't be this fragile.

As someone building email tools, seeing missing SPF configs is surprisingly common - even from big companies. The authentication trinity (SPF/DKIM/DMARC) really needs all three to work well, but SPF often gets forgotten.
